result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen capacities of agricultural* (incl. cropping, livestock husbandry and fisheries) communities to adapt to climate change in four vulnerable agro-ecological zones in Benin.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage change in vulnerability of agriculture (incl. animal husbandry), fisheries and food security sectors to climate risks via perception-based survey (VRA)

baseline.comment: Currently climate change risk is not explicitly integrated into PDCs, PRSP, and the Agricultural Revival Strategy

target.comment:
At mid-term 35% increase of VRA score
At end-of-project 70% of VRA score

actual.comment:
The Methodological Guide for the integration of adaptation to Climate Change in the local development planning is developed and available.
At the village level, annual adaptation action plans were developed in each of the 9 demonstration villages.
At the municipal level, three non-governmental organizations (NGOs) are recruited to support municipalities to proceed with the integration of considerations related to climate change in municipal development plans.
- Vulnerability studies and adaptation to climate change in the project intervention villages is in progress
At the National level, there have been initiatives such as:
- Decree establishing the national committee of economic modeling and integration of climate change in the general budget of the State;
- Development Strategy of Climate-Smart Agriculture within the framework of the West African alliance;
- Integration of climate change in the general budget of the State 2016-2018.
The different stages of methodological guidelines are followed to integrate climate change in these plans

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Capacity to plan for and respond to climate change in the agricultural sector improved.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of development planning and agriculture/fisheries related policies, programmes and plans incorporating climate change risks into their design

baseline.comment: Currently climate change risk is not explicitly integrated into PDCs, PRSP, and the Agricultural Revival Strategy

target.comment:
By the end of project:
- the PDCs in nine pilot Communes all integrate climate change risk into their design
- The PSRP specifically includes climate change risk
- The Agricultural Revival Strategy specifically includes climate change risk
- Specific budget is allocated within local development plan for the prevention of risk

actual.comment: At the start of PANA1 project in April 2011, there was no national support that can enable the integration of climate change considerations in local and national planning. But today, thanks to PANA1 project, there have been notable achievements are: - The Methodological Guide for the integration of adaptation to Climate Change in the local development planning is developed, validated and publishing; -The Local decision-makers and NGOs / Cabinets studies have been trained in the ACC integration approach in the PDCs; -Three (03) NGOs are recruited and contracts already signed for the integration of VAC in 9 PDC startup current of 9 common; - The study on "the development of a strategy for the integration of adaptation to CC in the plans / strategies for food security and agricultural production" is being finalized (suspended for lack of resources financial) - Agreement in preparation LoCAL with the project for the implementation of the ACC integration residual activities in the PDC - Development of an annual adaptation actions plan in each 9 project demonstration villages. - Each demonstration village is able to implement the adaptive measures plans. The technical departments involved in the implementation of PANA1 perfect in his fifteen monitoring work plan adaptation measures, within its sovereign powers, in the demonstration villages, but also, in other villages within its intervention area in its agricultural sector. The progress today is: (i) the publication and dissemination of the national integration of climate change considerations Guide; (ii) organizing workshops for the integration of climate change considerations in the Development Plans of 9 project demonstration villages; etc.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Number of development planning and agriculture/fisheries related policies, programmes and plans incorporating climate change risks into their design
(i) at local level - 9 PDC integrate considerations related to climate change and
(ii) at the national level, the Strategy for Growth and Reduction of Poverty (CPRS) and the Strategic Recovery Plan of Agricultural Areas (PSRSA) also integrate considerations related to climate change.

baseline.comment:
Currently climate change risk is not explicitly integrated into PDCs, PRSP, and the Agricultural Revival Strategy
No PDC has integrated adaptation to climate change
No national strategy has not yet integrated the climate change adaptation

target.comment:
(i) at local level - 9 PDC integrate considerations related to climate change and
(ii) at the national level, the Strategy for Growth and Reduction of Poverty (CPRS) and the Strategic Recovery Plan of Agricultural Areas (PSRSA) also integrate considerations related to climate change.

actual.comment:
Today, the integration of adaptation to climate change becomes more and more a reality.
The technical departments involved in the implementation of PANA1 perfect in there fifteen monitoring adaptation measures work plan, within its sovereign powers, in the demonstration villages, but also, in other intervention villages within its area in the agricultural sector. Nationally, 12 thematic studies covering various sectors of agriculture and food security have already been completed and bear prefaces and / or Foreword with the involvement of the project various structures technical partners. Among them, 11 were co-signed by the Minister in charge of Environment and Climate Change, the Minister in charge of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries and UNDP Resident Representative in Benin. Also, the Multidisciplinary Working Group for Agrometeorological Assistance (APWG) is reinforced today. He easily developed since January 2015, monthly agro-meteorological information bulletins "PANA1 AGROMET-INFO". As results there are -The Integration ACC guide in the PDCs is developed, validated and publishing; -The Local decision-makers and NGOs / Cabinets studies have been trained in the ACC integration approach in the PDCs; -Three (03) NGOs are recruited and contracts already signed for the integration of VAC in 9 PDC startup current of 9 common; - The study on "the development of a strategy for the integration of adaptation to CC in the plans / strategies for food security and agricultural production" is being finalized (suspended for lack of resources financial) - Agreement in preparation LoCAL with the project for the implementation of the ACC integration residual activities in the PDC - Development of an annual adaptation actions plan in each 9 project demonstration villages. The perspective today is: (i) the publication and dissemination of the national integration of climate change considerations Guide; (ii) organizing workshops for the integration of climate change considerations in the Development Plans of 9 project demonstration villages; etc.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Risk of climate induced impacts on agriculture productivity reduced

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of farmers (including pastoralist) and fishermen engaged in capacity development activities for climate change risk management

baseline.comment: Currently climate change risk is not explicitly integrated into PDCs, PRSP, and the Agricultural Revival Strategy

target.comment: 1. By mid-term at least 150 farmers and fishermen in 9 demonstration villages have been trained

actual.comment: It is obvious today that the implementation of PANA1 project contributed much understanding and interpretation of the climate hazards and climate extremes effects that face the country in general and agro-ecological zones most vulnerable. These four project focal zones namely are: (i) Zone 1: Far/Extreme North (Pilot commune: Malanville); (ii) Zone 4: West-North Atacora Donga (Pilot communes: Materi and Ouake; (iii) Zone 5: Central Cotton Zone (Cotonniere du Centre) (Pilot communes: Savalou and Aplahoue) and ; (iv) Zone 8: Fisheries (Pecheries) (Pilot communes: Bopa, So Ava, Adjohoun and Ouinhi). Locally, for granted, each demonstration village is able to develop today its adaptive measures plan to face climate change. The technical departments involved in the implementation of PANA1 perfect in there fifteen monitoring adaptation measures work plan, within its sovereign powers, in the demonstration villages, but also, in other intervention villages within its area in the agricultural sector. A total of 45 plans adaptive measures were developed at the 9 demonstration villages from 2011 to 2015. These plans incorporate good response adaptation measures to climate extremes and climate risks faced by each project intervention area. Nationally, 12 thematic studies covering various sectors of agriculture and food security have already been completed and bear prefaces and / or Foreword with the involvement of the project various structures technical partners. Among them, 11 were co-signed by the Minister in charge of Environment and Climate Change, the Minister in charge of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries and UNDP Resident Representative in Benin. Overall, the technical and intellectual substances in those thematic and technical studies allowed the development of 64 training materials (modules of trainer and learner modules). All these documents were integrated climate and extreme climate risks and the technical expertise and appropriate technical itineraries and new practices in terms of adaptation to climate change in agriculture, livestock, fisheries, agro-processing, supplies climatic and agro-climatic information and products, etc. All these studies and training materials were recorded during this PIR period the National Directorate of Archives and now carry each a number identifying ISB. Looking ahead, there is the progress of the training of farmers, ranchers, fishermen, processors of agricultural products including women as well.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage change in adaptative capacity in demonstration villages

baseline.comment: Currently climate change risk is not explicitly integrated into PDCs, PRSP, and the Agricultural Revival Strategy

target.comment: By the end of the project a total of 450 farmers and fishermen in the four agro-ecological zones have been trained

actual.comment: True, the project has developed 64 training documents (trainer modules and modules of the learner). These documents must be edited and expanded. A harmonized calendar with all involved structures public partners has been established. These structures are for most Responsible Parties. This is the Innovation Department of Agricultural and Operational Training Council (DICAF) as lead structure for training of producers, farmers, fishermen, agricultural products processors, etc. including women. It also has it, the Faculty of Agricultural Sciences (FSA), the Livestock Department, the Fisheries Department, the National Directorate of Meteorology (DNM), the Directorate of Plant Production (R / L), etc. These various structures continued through the appropriation of new adaptive technologies currently in demonstration villages, the beneficiaries of these technologies bulding. This is the case of the multiplication of soil off-fry pan, manufacture of food for fish and rabbits, the proliferation of short cycle seeds of maize and sorghum resilient to water stress, high rotting fish merchants floating cages, etc. To date, 1,738 farmers including 478 women have been trained in the technical itineraries adapted to climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of development planning and agriculture/fisheries related policies, programmes and plans incorporating climate change risks into their design

baseline.comment: Currently climate change risk is not explicitly integrated into PDCs, PRSP, and the Agricultural Revival Strategy

target.comment: 2. At end-of-project 70% of population in demonstration villages have good adaptive capacity

actual.comment: During this reporting period, the direct beneficiaries of the project have been several capacity building sessions and even recycling. This is, amongst other things: (i) Training of 12 leaders households including 4 women (fry multipliers) on fish farming techniques outside soil bins in the areas of fisheries PANA1 (Ouinhi, Adjohoun, Bopa and SÃ´-Ava) by the FSA; (ii) Training of farmers, herders and fishermen on technologies adapted to climate change; (iii) Making contact with researchers INRAB to acquire the basics of corn seeds; (iv) Provision of food to fry stocked in floating cages and fish pens (v) the second reproduction Clarias gariepinus fingerlings (catfish) and Oreochromis niloticus (Nile tilapia fish) suitable for short cycle and resilient aboveground bins in four (04) demonstration villages of the fishery zone (AEZ 8); (vi) Follow-up actions of the implementation of -actions research; (vii) Charging all floating cages and fish pens; (viii) Training of 12 leaders households including 4 women (fry multipliers) on fish farming techniques outside soil bins in the areas of fisheries PANA1 (Ouinhi, Adjohoun, Bopa and SÃ´-Ava) by the FSA; (ix) the second reproduction Clarias gariepinus fingerlings (catfish) and Oreochromis niloticus (Nile tilapia fish) suitable for short cycle and resilient Barcs above ground in four (04) demonstration villages of the fishery zone (AEZ; (x) 1760 kilo Harvest corn on the 20 kilo short-cycle seeds planted on 1ha (0,25 ha per village); (xi) Data collection on certified seed maize and sorghum trials and the culinary and sensory analysis in progress; (xii) exchange with beneficiaries on total production obtained and difficulties; (xiii) grouping of producers including 3 105 women in 7 demonstration villages (15 village demonstration by farmers for certified seed maize tests on a demonstration plot and 56 producers (8 demonstration by village) in the test adaptation of four varieties of sorghum in the operation of joint pana1 (Aplahoue Ouinhi,, Savalou Ouake Materi, Bopa and Malanville); (xiv) mastery of short cycle of seed production techniques; (xv) Advisory support to fish farmers trained in techniques and conducting fish farming in floating cages and pens; (xvi) IEC session organized by the D / Breeding cunicoles the benefit of farmers; (xvii) Support for the establishment of a crop storage system: construction of 4 storage / conservation infrastructure in the municipalities of Malanville, Materi, Ouake and Savalou.

target.comment: 3. will be based upon baseline survey undertaken (inception workshop should clarify so)

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Lessons learned and best practices from pilot activities, capacity development initiatives and policy changes dissiminated.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of lessons learned codified as relating to all three project outcomes

target.comment: At least 10 lessons learned per outcome codified

actual.comment:
The project had enough lessons learned and good practices. Among others, are: (i) Strong involvement of national authorities (the national party leadership) and local authorities in the implementation of the project: it is observed a strong commitment of the various stakeholders and project management bodies (UNDP, MEHU, CPP, CTP , CCTC resource Persons, EGP) during its implementation. Despite 15 months of delay experienced by the project before its official start in April 2011, it is noted significant achievements of the project in the 9 demonstration project villages; (ii) Operationalizing the Multidisciplinary Working Group for Agrometeorological Assistance (WGIP); (iii) All staff as provided in the Project Document and is a national counterpart in human resources is fully implemented; (iv) Permanent contact between project coordination, Mayors, ACPR, the RSCEPN, focal points allows ink to the base of project achievements; (v) Shares of adaptations to climate change identified by vulnerable communities fit quite well to their living conditions and development; (vi) Appropriation of mulching techniques (mulching) soil cultivation in some project demonstration villages optimizes crop yields; (vii) Autoproduction of intermediate seeds by the beneficiary communities of the project (viii) Opening Practice drains for disposal of surface water to the river Sô-Ava (ix) strengthening of National Meteorological park rainfall stations direct reading and 4 automatic agrometeorological stations; (x) Collecting rainfall and phenological data by local observers identified in each demonstration villages; (xi) Capacity building of these structures to the process of integration of climate change in studies, training modules; (xii) Development of an exit strategy and sustainability of the project PANA1.
All these lessons learned and good practices acquired currently subject to capitalization. UNDP canvas.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Benin.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard.
2. Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

baseline.comment:
1. Limited capacity to generate EWS and CI on a national scale for extreme hydro-meteorological phenomena. Limited disaster risk-prevention capacity on national and local levels within ANPC. No Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for alert communication by ANPC with the support of NGOs/CSOs.
Current score: 62
2. Existing budget plans do not have sufficient funds to maintain and operate the environmental monitoring infrastructure.

target.comment:
1. Capacity assessment target score of 157 for all combined EWS agencies.
2. 40% increase in domestic financing for equipment operation and maintenance across all institutions.

actual.comment:
The EWS capacity for the mitigation of flooding risks has been created at the level of national institutions. Current Score = 90
Standard Operating Procedures for alert communication have been adopted by the Government.
Planned domestic financing is done. An amount of 30,000 USD (around 10% increase) is funded bu domestic resources in 2014 and 246,200 USD is planned for 2015.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced capacity of national hydro-meteorological services (DNM/DG-Eau) and coastal monitoring institutions (CRHOB) to monitor extreme weather and climate change (droughts, floods, strong winds, coastal erosion, sea- level rise).

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. % national coverage for climate/weather monitoring.
2. Frequency and timeliness of climate-related data availability.

baseline.comment:
1. Currently, there is approximately 30% national coverage for climate/weather monitoring with respect to the optimal arrangements, as defined in the NHMS feasibility reports. 6 manual synoptic weather stations, 2 manual agro-climatological stations, 55 manual rainfall gauges, 2 manual flow meters (water level), 46 automatic flow meters (water level), 1 ADCP and 1 coastal monitoring station are in place.
2. Data from manual weather and hydrological stations is collected monthly and transmitted by post.

target.comment:
1. 60% national coverage to take steps in achieving NHMS optimal monitoring arrangements as defined in feasibility studies with 76 automatic flow meters (water level), 2 ADCPs, 3 automatic agro-meteorological/ climate stations, 2 automatic synoptic stations, 55 automatic rain gauges and rehabilitation of 6 manual synoptic stations and 20 manual agro-climatological stations.
2. Target for data transmission frequency: daily.

actual.comment:
The following equipment is currently being procured and will be delivered in a few weeks: 3 automatic synoptic stations, 7 agro-climatic stations, 140 limnimetric staff-gauges, 20 automatic limnimetric recorders, 1 sea buoy, 2 multi-parameters and portable analysers of sea water, 2 ADCP (river and sea water) automatic flow and bathymetric measurement. The dispcrepacies between the procured equipments listed here and the target planned is due to some adaptation of the target specified in Project Document. During the time between Project Formulation end and Project beginning, the need of national institutions is progress and the news targets were adopted by national institutions in the framework of Project launching workshop.
The water level for the main rivers is already being transmitted daily to the EWS server. The system is not yet operational for met data or oceano data.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Efficient and effective use of hydro-meteorological and coastal information for making early warnings and seasonal forecasts which feed into long-term development plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. % of population with access to improved climate information and flood, drought, strong wind and coastal warnings (disaggregated by gender).
2. Development frameworks (The Poverty Reduction Strategy paper, PRSP (French: SCRP), the Programme d’Action Prioritaires (PAP), the Environmental Management Plan (PNDC-GEM) and the Agricultural Revival Strategy, NGSPR ) that integrate climate information in their formulation of poverty reduction strategies at the local levels.
3. Sector-specific strategies and plans that integrate climate risks (agriculture, health, and cotton production sectors).

baseline.comment:
1. There are 4 existing EWS initiatives for regional flood warnings and famine alerts, however, a national alert system concerned with extreme hydro-meteorological phenomena is lacking. There is also a limited understanding of the technical alert jargon (alerts are not translated into all national languages). There is also no mechanism for end-users (most vulnerable populations) to be involved in the alert process to ensure its sustainability.
2. Development frameworks do not incorporate any EWS/CI products such as risk maps or climate change predictions into long-term planning.
3. Sector-specific strategies do not include EWS/CI because the quality of weather forecasts and climate predictions is poor and not tailored for specific uses, particularly seasonal forecasts.

target.comment:
1. 50% increase in the population who has access to improved EWS/CI.
2. At least 2 of the PRSP policy briefs incorporate analyses of risk maps and/or climate change projections influencing long-term planning proposals. Target: integration into the revised SCRP (by 2015), PAP (by 2015) and NGSPR (by 2016).
3. Development of at least two tailored climate products and presentation of a market research plan on how to implement mobile phone based agricultural advisories, both supporting targeted weather/climate service delivery.

actual.comment:
1. Percentage not yet assessed, but more people located in flooding areas (13 districts of Lower valley of Oueme River, 5 districts of Lower valley of Mono River and 2 boundary districts of Niger River) have quick access to warning messages on this risk (around 800,000 persons). Seasonal agro-hydro-climatic messages were disseminated in 14 local languages through 16 local meetings with farmers and producers (more than 500 farmers).
2. No progress at the current date
3. No progress at the current date

iati-activity.title: Programme d'Alimentation en Eau Potable en Milieu Rural
iati-activity.description: Ce Programme permettra d’accroître le taux de desserte et d’accès à l’eau potable des populations non encore couvertes dans 54 communes du Bénin couvrant 307 villages.
